document_metadata.title: Stage 1 Orientation - Corporate, Legal, and Structural Reality

stage_1_intent.primary_purpose: Establish structural, legal, and control reality of target entity before business performance or operational analysis
discovery_domains: Legal entity structure and jurisdictional exposures
Ownership chains, control mechanisms, and beneficial ownership reality
Contractual obligations that constrain or encumber the entity
Regulatory status, licensing requirements, and compliance posture
Material legal proceedings, liens, judgments, and encumbrances
Corporate governance structure and fiduciary relationships
Debt covenants, change-of-control triggers, and structural constraints
why_stage_1_precedes_others: Financial analysis is meaningless if ownership or entity structure is misunderstood
Operational assessments fail if regulatory constraints or contractual obligations are unknown
Risk analysis cannot be performed without understanding legal liabilities
Strategic options are bounded by structural reality (debt covenants, ownership structures, regulatory status)
truths_not_fixable_retroactively: Misidentification of legal entity being analyzed - all subsequent work analyzes wrong target
Missed material encumbrances (liens, guarantees, covenants) - downstream financial projections become fictional
Failed control structure mapping - negotiation with parties lacking authority
Ignored regulatory constraints - operational plans may be legally impossible
Late-discovered structural realities trigger complete rework of all downstream stages

prohibited_activities: Assess business model viability or competitive positioning
Evaluate management quality or operational effectiveness
Analyze financial performance, profitability, or cash generation
Make recommendations about organizational structure changes
Propose solutions to identified structural problems
Conclude whether structural characteristics are good or bad for investment
Compare target structure to ideal forms or best practices
Design integration plans, restructuring approaches, or remediation strategies
prohibited_analysis_types: Strategic implications of structure (discovery only, not interpretation for strategy)
Valuation adjustments based on structural findings
Market position or competitive advantage analysis
boundary_violations: Using prescriptive phrases: 'should restructure', 'recommend simplification', 'needs to'
Characterizing structural features as 'strengths' or 'weaknesses' relative to investment thesis
Proposing corporate actions, entity consolidations, or governance changes
Extrapolating from structure to business performance without evidence

invalidation_triggers.description: Analysis examines subsidiary when parent is target, or vice versa; incorrect jurisdiction; operating entity confused with holding entity
Beneficial ownership unclear; control mechanisms not traced to ultimate authority; voting vs. economic rights discrepancies unexplored
Debt covenants not reviewed; guarantees and cross-defaults undiscovered; regulatory consent requirements overlooked; change-of-control provisions missed
Material proceedings dismissed without analysis; contingent liabilities ignored; regulatory investigations unreported
Reliance on management narrative instead of formation documents; using press releases instead of SEC filings; treating summaries as primary evidence

false_completeness_indicators: Analysis appears comprehensive but relies on single source (e.g., only 10-K, not formation docs)
Corporate structure chart shown without verification against secretary of state records
Debt described without reviewing actual credit agreements
Regulatory status claimed without checking licensing databases
No material litigation stated based on absence of disclosure, not active search
downstream_lies: Omitting 'immaterial' entities that house critical assets or liabilities
Characterizing litigation as 'routine' when dollar exposure is material
Stating entity is 'in compliance' when evidence only shows absence of disclosed violations
Failing to distinguish between contractual obligations and management assertions

assumptions_from_stage_1: Financial statements correspond to entity being analyzed
Debt obligations are completely identified for leverage calculations
No undisclosed liens or encumbrances affecting asset values
stage_2_financial_analysis.failure_propagation: If Stage 1 misses off-balance-sheet entities or contingent liabilities, Stage 2 financial metrics are systematically wrong

assumptions_from_stage_1: Regulatory constraints on markets/products are known
Contractual relationships with customers/partners are within corporate authority
stage_3_business_model.failure_propagation: If Stage 1 misses regulatory prohibitions, Stage 3 may analyze revenue streams that are legally impermissible

assumptions_from_stage_1: Identified entity owns or controls assets being assessed
No contractual restrictions on technology use or IP ownership
stage_4_operational_technology.failure_propagation: If Stage 1 misidentifies asset ownership (owned vs. licensed), Stage 4 may assess capabilities that don't transfer in acquisition

assumptions_from_stage_1: Stage 1 identified regulatory baseline and litigation inventory
All material compliance obligations are known
stage_5_risk_compliance.failure_propagation: If Stage 1 misses regulatory requirements, Stage 5 risk assessment understates compliance risk

assumptions_from_stage_1: Stage 1 correctly identified what entity is being analyzed
stage_6_synthesis.failure_propagation: If Stage 1 is wrong about entity structure, entire diligence analyzes wrong target or operates under false assumptions

cross_stage_assumption_errors: Assuming entity can take actions that covenants prohibit
Assuming ownership of assets that are actually leased or licensed
Assuming regulatory permissions that don't exist
Assuming clean title when liens exist
Assuming single entity when multiple entities must be separately analyzed

stage_1_hypothesis_register.governance_note: Per Stage 0.3 requirements: hypotheses must be falsifiable, structural (not performance-based), evidence-based (not narrative-based)

hypotheses.hypothesis: The target operates through a multi-tiered entity structure with subsidiaries in multiple jurisdictions, creating layered ownership and potential regulatory complexity
supporting_evidence_sources: SEC filings listing multiple subsidiary entities
State/international corporate registry searches showing subsidiary registrations
Organizational charts in proxy statements showing holding company structure
Credit agreements referencing multiple borrower/guarantor entities
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Single entity registration with no subsidiaries listed in formation documents
Financial statements showing no intercompany transactions or consolidations
Regulatory filings identifying only one operating entity
Corporate formation documents showing simple single-entity structure
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Search secretary of state databases, SEC Exhibit 21 (subsidiaries), credit agreement schedules, and regulatory filings for subsidiary listings

hypotheses.hypothesis: The target operates under debt agreements containing financial covenants, change-of-control provisions, and operational restrictions that materially constrain corporate actions
supporting_evidence_sources: Credit agreements containing financial maintenance covenants (leverage ratios, coverage ratios)
Change-of-control definitions and consent requirements in debt documents
Negative covenants restricting liens, asset sales, dividends, or additional debt
SEC filings disclosing covenant compliance status or waivers
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Covenant-lite loan agreements with no financial maintenance requirements
Absence of debt on balance sheet and no credit facility agreements
Unrestricted debt structures with no operational constraints
Public statements confirming unencumbered balance sheet
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Review actual credit agreements (not summaries), search SEC filings for covenant discussions, examine financial statement footnotes for debt terms

hypotheses.hypothesis: The target operates in regulated industries requiring licenses, permits, or ongoing regulatory compliance that creates jurisdictional dependencies and operational constraints
supporting_evidence_sources: Operating licenses required in specific states/countries for business conduct
Regulatory filings with industry-specific agencies (FCC, state banking, healthcare, etc.)
Compliance obligations disclosed in SEC filings or annual reports
Regulatory consent requirements for ownership changes
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Business model operates in unregulated industry
No specialized licenses required beyond basic business registrations
Absence of regulatory agency filings or oversight relationships
10-K risk factors section lacks regulatory compliance discussion
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Search regulatory agency databases, review 10-K regulatory discussion sections, check state licensing boards, examine industry-specific compliance requirements

hypotheses.hypothesis: The target is party to material litigation, regulatory investigations, or legal proceedings that create contingent liabilities or operational constraints beyond routine commercial disputes
supporting_evidence_sources: Legal proceedings disclosed in 10-K/10-Q with material dollar exposure
Ongoing regulatory investigations disclosed in SEC filings
Securities class actions or derivative suits naming the entity
Recorded contingent liabilities in financial statement footnotes
disconfirming_evidence_sources: 10-K legal proceedings section states no material litigation
PACER federal court docket searches return no material cases
Financial statements show no contingent liability reserves
State court searches reveal only routine contract disputes below materiality threshold
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Search PACER federal dockets, state court systems, SEC litigation disclosures, regulatory enforcement databases (SEC, DOJ, FTC)

hypotheses.hypothesis: The target has concentrated ownership or control held by private equity sponsors, founder-insiders, or institutional blocks that creates principal-agent dynamics and potential conflicts in decision-making
supporting_evidence_sources: Proxy statements (DEF 14A) showing >20% ownership blocks
Dual-class share structures with differential voting rights
Private equity ownership disclosed in press releases or SEC filings
Board composition dominated by sponsor-affiliated directors
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Widely dispersed public ownership with no >5% holders
Single-class common stock with one-share-one-vote structure
Independent board majority with no controlling shareholder
Public company with no disclosed beneficial owners above reporting thresholds
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Review DEF 14A beneficial ownership tables, Schedule 13D/13G filings for >5% holders, corporate charter for share class structures, board composition disclosures
